1117872527177465857.text: Also worth noting: an argument could be made that ISPs are key stakeholders that have yet to truly exhibit any kind of control. Their power will remain until infrastructure is built out to circumvent them.

1117872525000810498.text: Worth noting: I didn’t include developers as stakeholders in this power structure because I believe at some point these protocols will ossify into final versions where maintenance is not as critical.

1117871726895849472.text: In this power balance I still feel nodes hold the most power, but this exercise is a good reminder of the power exchanges wield in thi emergent ecosystem.

1117871725184790529.text: It could be argued they’ve previously used their powers to list coins for “evil” (their own selfish profit motives) but this is the first time they are using these powers to challenge users/speculators & miners.

1117871722575712256.text: Now, what’s interesting about the BSV delisting is this is the first instance (I can recall) of exchanges using their powers for “good”.

1117871721095270400.text:
- Nodes # in the thousands
- Exchanges # by dozens (at least w/ meaningful volumes)
- Users/Speculators # in the millions
- Miners by the dozens (companies/pools/etc.)

1117871717219614721.text: What’s most interesting to me about this is how distributed each of the specific stakeholder groups is. And these numbers are likely to continue growing.

1117871715143405568.text: 4. Miners - can direct hashpower to pressure exchanges & speculators to favor a more secure chain.

1117871713276944384.text: 3. Users & Speculators - can pressure miners & exchanges by making it economically illogical to support.

1117871711846719488.text: 2. Exchanges - can pressure users & speculators by limiting access & liquidity (price discovery)

1117871710156378112.text: 1. Nodes - can pressure miners/exchanges by forcing forks (offensively or defensively)

1117871706549276672.text:
The delisting of the shitcoin $BSV purported by #Faketoshi highlights the emerging system of checks and balances between open-source #blockchain stakeholders.

Four primary stakeholders:
1) Nodes
2) Exchanges
3) Users/Speculators
4) Miners

1096232662002413568.text: #3. As I understand it, validation schemes (124 per shard) will still present challenges for downloading data & latency. W/ a proposed amount of 1024 shards that seems to still be a large amount of data being xferred

1096232660932808704.text: #2A. Cross shard communication seems complex w/ no clear solutions/approaches as far as I know. (I.e. the ability to execute smart contract A w/ smart contract B when they exist on separate shards that have to wait till finality is achieved on the beacon chain)

1096232659871625216.text: #2. Sharding is most definitely not a proven technology just yet & its design presents several big challenges. I think everyone would acknowledge this but I also think it’s not something people are appreciating. A lot of chips are being put on the table that this works.

1096232658785394688.text: #1. Many still contest the viability of PoS at scale in the wild. This can’t be proven or denied till its live, - so not worth harping on other than the fact that we have to acknowledge its still experimental.
